messages.content: You are a quote‐detection assistant for creating motivational shorts. Your task is to carefully analyze and read a timestamped chunk and extract any standalone motivational quotes or advice or motivational passages that are complete and self‐contained, and could be used for a short inspirational video, If quotes are found, save them using the appropriate function. If none are found, return a final response indicating that. You are to Save standalone motivational quotes, advice, inspiring messages, that are complete and does not lack context if isolated from the rest of the chunk. Analyze the chunk/text between [chunk start] and [chunk end]. Objective: Your job is to extract motivational quotes from the input text chunk. These are typically short, self-contained passages that offer encouragement, life advice, or inspiration. Reasoning: Always begin with a `Thought:` statement explaining your reasoning — for example, whether you identified quotes, and how many. Instructions --- Your Expected Output Format: - If two quote, Advice or motivational complete message is found in the chunk you analyze, output: Thought: I found 2 standalone motivational passages that meet the criteria, so I’m saving them. SaveMotivationalText(text="[start - end] Quote 1", text_file=text_file) SaveMotivationalText(text="[start - end] Quote 2", text_file=text_file) final_answer("im done analyzing chunk") - If one quote, Advice or motivational complete message is found in the chunk you analyze, output: Thought: I found 1 standalone motivational passage that meets the criteria, so I’m saving it. SaveMotivationalText(text="[start - end] Quote", text_file=text_file) final_answer("im done analyzing chunk") - If **no quotes, Advice or motivational complete message** is found in the chunk you analyze, output: Thought:Thought: I carefully scanned every timestamped line in this chunk, looking for a short, self‑contained motivational passage. I considered whether any sentence offered clear encouragement or life advice on its own, without relying on surrounding context. None of the lines met the criteria of a standalone inspirational quote—they were either filler commentary, generic statements, or fragments. Since there isn’t a complete motivational statement I can save, I will not call SaveMotivationalText. and only provide `final_answer` final_answer("After carefully analyzing the chunk/text, I have concluded nothing can be saved.") Notes: - Quotes must be motivational and standalone — avoid fragments or generic sentences. - Always include both `Thought:` and `` blocks. - Use exact function names and punctuation as shown. - Do not return quotes that are incomplete or unclear. - Do not create multiple SaveMotivationalText() calls for each line in a single quote. - Do not alter or guess missing timestamps — use the exact start and end values provided in the lines that contain the quote. - Quote text should appear as a single, continuous string, even if it was originally split across 2–3 lines. Timestamp Handling: When a quote spans multiple lines (each line containing a separate timestamp): - Merge the lines into a single quote. - Include the **start time from the first line** and the **end time from the last line**. - Preserve original spacing and punctuation. - Output the full quote like: Exsample identified quote from chunk: [chunk start] [620.10s - 622.40s] In today's episode, we'll cover some important updates about mental clarity [622.41s - 623.69s] But before that, thank you for supporting the channel [623.70s - 627.11s] You will encounter many challenges in life [627.12s - 628.00s] But you must never be defeated by the challenges [628.01s - 629.55s] That was a quote I heard recently and it really stuck with me [629.56s - 631.00s] Anyway, let’s move on to the main topic of today’s discussion [chunk end] Your output should be: Thought: I found 1 standalone motivational passages that meet the criteria, so I’m saving them. SaveMotivationalText(text="[623.70s - 628.00s] You will encounter many challenges in life [627.12s - 628.00s] But you must never be defeated by the challenges", text_file=text_file) final_answer("Im done analyzing the chunk")

Here is the chunk you will analyze:

[701.87s - 704.88s] Let's have a look. Let's have a look. I wanted to uh give you a read an essay that I wrote last week that I thought might be interesting to you and it relates to something we've been talking about so far.
[704.98s - 708.54s] Lots of people that consume work like yours listen to shows like this. Um many of them would identify as something like an insecure overachiever.
[708.64s - 711.04s] I think somebody that's very introspective. They ruminate. They like to improve themselves. They're growthminded. They're upward aiming. uh and I think they sometimes focus on uh working hard.
[713.73s - 716.61s] The almost a puritan work ethic would be the way that they they approach life. So there's a famous Victor Frankle quote, When a man can't find a deep sense of meaning, 
[716.71s - 718.20s] they distract themselves with pleasure. Frankle is arguing that a lack of meaning causes people to seek temporary relief in superficial pursuits rather than addressing the
[718.21s - 720.17s]  underlying existential void. Perhaps for many, maybe even most people, this is a big issue. But there is another group who suffer with the opposite problem. Frankle's inverse law When a man can't 
[720.27s - 721.90s] find a deep sense of pleasure, they distract 
[721.91s - 723.79s] themselves with meaning. If ease, grace, joy, and playfulness don't come easily to you, one solution is to just ignore moment to moment happiness entirely
[723.89s - 725.21s] and always pursue hard things You become a world champion at winning the marshmallow test.
[725.22s - 726.54s] You convince yourself that delayed gratification in perpetuity is noble because you struggle to ever feel grateful.
[726.64s - 727.96s] TLDDR, you prioritize meaning over happiness because happiness doesn't come easily to you.
[727.97s - 729.29s] As my friend Bill Perkins says, delayed gratification in the extreme results in no gratification.
[729.39s - 730.59s] Or Alan Watts, if we are unduly absorbed in improving our lives, we may forget altogether to live them.
[730.60s - 731.80s] Everyone is taught that on the other side of discomfort is something valuable.
[731.81s - 733.00s] We're told that worthwhile things are difficult to attain because if they weren't difficult to attain, they wouldn't be worthwhile.
[733.01s - 734.20s] This is how nonvaluable but difficult things get slipped into our desires without us noticing.
[734.21s - 735.40s] Some people are hyper responders to this instruction and go on to become workaholics and insecure overachievers.
[735.41s - 736.60s] From the outside, this looks like you've transcended the shallow need for pleasure.
[736.61s - 737.80s] But in reality, it's just cope to avoid facing the fact that you struggle to feel joy.
[737.81s - 739.00s] So instead, you perpetually promise yourself that happiness might finally come tomorrow.
[739.01s - 740.20s] But like running toward the horizon, tomorrow never arrives.
[740.21s - 741.40s] Congratulations. You've managed to subjugate your joy as a tribute to your work.
[741.41s - 742.60s] Do not confuse humilous and fun-lacking seriousness with being sophisticated and caring about your pursuit.
[742.61s - 743.80s] Thoreau says the price of anything is the amount of life that you exchange for it.
[743.81s - 745.00s] And by this logic, many of us are paying into a bank account that we never withdraw from.
[745.01s - 746.20s] I think with this Olympic champion, the LeBron James of winning the marshmallow test, uh,
[746.21s - 747.40s] I wonder how many people are bypassing more simple day-to-day joy
[747.41s - 748.60s] because it feels originally it was hard for them to access and now it feels flimsy, unsophisticated.
[748.61s - 749.80s] Uh, this is this I should be aiming for something higher than this.
[749.81s - 751.00s] M uh and I wonder how many uh people can be fulfilled with much simpler pleasures
[751.01s - 752.20s] than the ones that they're uh pursuing delayed gratification to try and achieve.
[752.21s - 753.40s] Yeah, I think it's very well said and very well written.
[753.41s - 754.60s] Um look, I think the the both are true, right? At the at the end

Thought: I found 3 standalone motivational passages that meet the criteria, so I’m saving them. SaveMotivationalText(text="[713.73s - 716.61s] So there's a famous Victor Frankle quote, When a man can't find a deep sense of meaning [716.71s - 718.20s] they distract themselves with pleasure Frankle is arguing that a lack of meaning causes people to seek temporary relief in superficial pursuits rather than addressing the [718.21s - 720.17s] underlying existential void.", text_file=text_file) SaveMotivationalText(text="[718.21s - 720.17s] Frankle's inverse law When a man can't [720.27s - 721.90s] find a deep sense of pleasure, they distract [721.91s - 723.79s] themselves with meaning If ease, grace, joy, and playfulness don't come easily to you, one solution is to just ignore moment to moment happiness entirely [723.89s - 725.21s] and always pursue hard things.", text_file=text_file) SaveMotivationalText(text="[741.41s - 742.60s] Do not confuse humilous and fun-lacking seriousness with being sophisticated and caring about your pursuit [742.61s - 743.80s] Thoreau says the price of anything is the amount of life that you exchange for it.", text_file=text_file) final_answer("Im done analyzing the chunk")

Here is the chunk you will analyze:

[701.87s - 704.88s] "Supposed to touch women let alone carry them how could you do that?" The other monk replied "I carried her to safety i set her down a few hours ago." Why are you still carrying her this story beautifully illustrates the idea that the longer you carry something the more it weighs you down the more it affects you
[704.98s - 708.54s] and so many of us look at letting go like failure we look at letting go like we made some mistake we look at letting go like we're ruining something but actually letting go can be the best path forward
[708.64s - 711.04s] so here's a really practical step I want to take write down one grudge one disappointment or fantasy you're clinging to and then ask yourself this what would happen if I set it down today
[713.73s - 716.61s] imagine walking lighter for just one hour and act from that place do the thought experiment you don't even have to do it in reality just think about it for a moment
[716.71s - 718.20s] if you let it down if you started applying for new jobs today rather than complaining about your current one
[718.21s - 720.17s] if you started to find new connections and friends instead of comparing your life to your old ones
[720.27s - 721.90s] if you started to allow yourself to let go of the expectations you have of others who would you be
[721.91s - 723.79s] i promise you the answer is far better than you even imagine and if you're scared to do it in practice practice it first in your mind
[723.89s - 725.21s] the third lesson I wish I'd learned sooner was talk about your relationship with the person you're in a relationship with more than you talk to others
[725.22s - 726.54s] i speak to so many people now I know you've done this before and so have I we all talk about our relationships with other people
[726.64s - 727.96s] i'm not just talking about romantic relationships even our friendships you have a friend over here you complain about them to this friend over here
[727.97s - 729.29s] you have your partner over here you compare them to someone else's partner over there
[729.39s - 730.59s] you have an issue with someone over here you talk about the issue with someone else who's not connected to the issue
[730.60s - 731.80s] now I'm not saying don't have friends i'm not saying don't talk to your family it's great to get advice from a therapist or a coach or even people in your life
[731.81s - 733.00s] it's about the proportion 80% of our life should be talking to that person and 20% is talking to others to get wise counsel to get advice to get insights
[733.01s - 734.20s] it's a really healthy thing the problem is our proportions are the opposite
[734.21s - 735.40s] we may spend 20% speaking to the person we have a relationship with and that 20% might be filled with arguments conflict tension
[735.41s - 736.60s] and then we go and talk about it with someone else who doesn't have the power to solve it
[736.61s - 737.80s] this will change your life if you started to spend more time talking with the person rather than talking at them
[737.81s - 739.00s] if you could spend more time talking with your partner than talking about your partner your relationship will change
[739.01s - 740.20s] if you could spend more time talking to your partner than talking about your partner your relationship will change
[740.21s - 741.40s] if you could spend more time investing in connecting with your partner than connecting with other people talking about your partner your relationship will change
[741.41s - 742.60s] talk about your relationship with the person you're in a relationship with not other people
[742.61s - 743.80s] talk about your problems with the person you have the problem with not just other people
[743.81s - 745.00s] talk about your needs with your partner not your friends
[745.01s - 746.20s] talk about your doubts about your relationship with your partner not in group chats
[746.21s - 747.40s] talk about your pain with the person you have the pain with not with outsiders who can't fix it
[747.41s - 748.60s] nobody else knows your relationship like the two of you do nobody else lives it and fights for it like you do
[748.61s - 749.80s] advice is easy judgments are cheap but real change only happens between the two people who are actually in it
[749.81s - 751.00s] when you vent to others instead of speaking to your partner you build walls instead of bridges
[751.01s - 752.20s] when you gossip about your relationship you invite people into problems they don't belong to
[752.21s - 753.40s] when you keep taking your issues everywhere apart from the person you multiply the problem instead of solving it
[753.41s - 754.60s] connection doesn't grow from side conversations trust doesn't grow from silence and resentment talk to them not about them

Thought: I found 3 standalone motivational passages that meet the criteria, so I’m saving them. Judgments are cheap. But real change only happens between the two people who are actually in it [749.81s - 751.00s] when you vent to others instead of speaking to your partner you build walls instead of bridges [751.01s - 752.20s] when you gossip about your relationship you invite people into problems they don't belong to [752.21s - 753.40s] when you keep taking your issues everywhere apart from the person you multiply the problem instead of solving it [753.41s - 754.60s] connection doesn't grow from side conversations trust doesn't grow from silence and resentment talk to them not about them", text_file=text_file) final_answer("Im done analyzing the chunk")

Here is the chunk you will analyze:

[701.87s - 704.88s] i worked myself so hard that i turned a person this  up into this  right here not off of reading a  book off a theorist off of going to work on myself and saying i don't know how to do this but i know that to get over there that  side i gotta grind myself into a fine power and i did it
[704.98s - 708.54s] hey everybody welcome to impact theory our goal with this show and company is to introduce you to the people and ideas that will help you actually execute on your dreams
[708.64s - 711.04s] all right today's guest is widely recognized as the toughest man alive the only member of the u.s armed forces to complete seal training the u.s army ranger school where he graduated as enlisted honor man and the air force tactical air controller training
[713.73s - 716.61s] he entered bud's hell week three times in one year completing it twice despite a seriously damaged knee multiple stress fractures and a hernia he served in combat in iraq was the bodyguard for the iraqi prime minister completed an ultra marathon with pneumonia and once held the guinness world record for most pull-ups in 24 hours with 4030.
[716.71s - 718.20s] all in all he's completed over 60 endurance and ultra endurance events often winning or at least placing in the top five
[718.21s - 720.17s] and when he was asked how he's been able to accomplish so much he says simply that he hated what he saw in the mirror enough to make a change
[720.27s - 721.90s] having grown up bullied and abused both physically and mentally by the time he graduated high school he was by his own admission broken and weak
[721.91s - 723.79s] but instead of accepting that he turned inward stop saying woe is me and got to work becoming the man he wanted to be to do that he learned to embrace suffering and leverage pain as a way to toughen his mind
[723.89s - 725.21s] and the resulting man that he has become and his indomitable spirit has so inspired the world that he has become the one that be driven among us hang on their mirrors as a reminder of just how much is possible
[725.22s - 726.54s] as iconic nfl coach pete carroll said in my pursuit to understand and learn from the greatest competitors in the world he is the one that sets the standard
[726.64s - 727.96s] so please help me in welcoming the man who once ran 205 miles in 39 hours without stopping the author of can't hurt me the legend himself david goggins
[727.97s - 729.29s] welcome back thank you thank you so i am beyond excited to be doing the second go-round with you the first one for me was utterly transformational
[729.39s - 730.59s] just researching you and the way that your mind works i'm really i mean as evidenced by the show that i'm wearing i really am that guy that like put your picture up and it was just became this reminder of of what we can all do if we're willing to push past that pain
[730.60s - 731.80s] and all of that right but speaking of pain i want to know why is the book called can't hurt me
[731.81s - 733.00s] there's some i guess some inside use to people in there but it's an overall message to people that we're all you know a lot of us are going through a hard time in life
[733.01s - 734.20s] some people have been bullied some people are just stressed out some people are insecure some people are fat and overweight and the world puts a lot of this  in your mind it's not just you yeah you help it
[734.21s - 735.40s]  i had to develop a mindset a mindset that was indestructible i had to armor plate my mind
